title: Combination of content provider allows private data disclosure

profile.name: Nextcloud
profile.about: Access, share and protect your files, calendars, contacts, communication & more at home and in your enterprise.

vulnerability_information:
Good afternoon.

Sorry, its me again .. I use NC on a daily basis so I often makes some checks ..

As per #489105, document thumbnail shall not be disclosed. The exposure on thumbnailCache/ is an already know issue.  However, malicious apps are still able to extract (at least) pictures and text files by combining two content provider results.

As discussed in #518669, file status is exposed. This allow basically any app to retreive NC storage file structures. The  following endpoint is the relevant one for current issue:
```adb shell content query --uri content://org.nextcloud/file ```

which output for instance
```Row: 1 _id=7, filename=1553357105332.jpg, encrypted_filename=NULL, path=/1553357105332.jpg, parent=1, created=0, modified=1553357105000, content_type=image/jpeg, content_length=1275, media_path=, file_owner=julien_contacts@cloud.local.yourosoft.com, last_sync_date=1554908710211, keep_in_sync=NULL, last_sync_date_for_data=1554908492289, modified_at_last_sync_for_data=1553357105000, etag=1181bc97f9637dc926b9a5eddd618c7b, share_by_link=0, public_link=, permissions=RGDNVW, remote_id=00087789oc2tsz873825, update_thumbnail=0, is_downloading=0, favorite=0, is_encrypted=0, etag_in_conflict=NULL, shared_via_users=0, mount_type=0, has_preview=1, unread_comments_count=0, etag_on_server=1181bc97f9637dc926b9a5eddd618c7b, owner_id=julien_contacts, owner_display_name=Julien (Contact sync), note=
```

By using the output from this content provider query, it is possible to force the DiskLruImageCacheFileProvider content provider to generate thumbnail of the assets
adb shell content read --uri content://org.nextcloud.imageCache.provider/1553357105332.jpg

## Impact

User data is exposed to partial  disclosure (thumbnail).

As far as I understand, DiskLruImageCacheFileProvider shall not be exported

Good afternoon.

Sorry, its me again .. I use NC on a daily basis so I often makes some checks ..

As per #489105, document thumbnail shall not be disclosed. The exposure on thumbnailCache/ is an already know issue. However, malicious apps are still able to extract (at least) pictures and text files by combining two content provider results.

As discussed in #518669, file status is exposed. This allow basically any app to retreive NC storage file structures. The following endpoint is the relevant one for current issue:
adb shell content query --uri content://org.nextcloud/file

which output for instance
```Row: 1 _id=7, filename=1553357105332.jpg, encrypted_filename=NULL, path=/1553357105332.jpg, parent=1, created=0, modified=1553357105000, content_type=image/jpeg, content_length=1275, media_path=, file_owner=julien_contacts@cloud.local.yourosoft.com, last_sync_date=1554908710211, keep_in_sync=NULL, last_sync_date_for_data=1554908492289, modified_at_last_sync_for_data=1553357105000, etag=1181bc97f9637dc926b9a5eddd618c7b, share_by_link=0, public_link=, permissions=RGDNVW, remote_id=00087789oc2tsz873825, update_thumbnail=0, is_downloading=0, favorite=0, is_encrypted=0, etag_in_conflict=NULL, shared_via_users=0, mount_type=0, has_preview=1, unread_comments_count=0, etag_on_server=1181bc97f9637dc926b9a5eddd618c7b, owner_id=julien_contacts, owner_display_name=Julien (Contact sync), note=


By using the output from this content provider query, it is possible to force the DiskLruImageCacheFileProvider content provider to generate thumbnail of the assets
adb shell content read --uri content://org.nextcloud.imageCache.provider/1553357105332.jpg

## Impact

As far as I understand, DiskLruImageCacheFileProvider shall not be exported

activities.message:
Thanks a lot for reporting this potential issue back to us!

Our security team will take a look at this issue as soon as possible. We will reply to your report within 72 hours, usually much faster. For obvious reasons we'd like to ask you to not disclose this issue to any other party.
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks a lot for reporting this potential issue back to us!

Our security team will take a look at this issue as soon as possible. We will reply to your report within 72 hours, usually much faster. For obvious reasons we'd like to ask you to not disclose this issue to any other party.

activities.message:
Hi,

You can already access thumbnails by browsing them via a storage providers (open document/file and chose nextcloud). Or does this leak more info?

Cheers,
--Roeland
activities.markdown_message:
Hi,

You can already access thumbnails by browsing them via a storage providers (open document/file and chose nextcloud). Or does this leak more info?

Cheers,
--Roeland

activities.message:
Hi Roeland.

As per #489105, the fact that thumbnails are available via a storage providers is explained by two reasons.
a. files are public (i.e. Nextcloud storage is on /sdcard)
b. files are NOT public yet thumbnails are exposed

for (a), I agree.
for (b), the issue comes with the underlying thumbnail generation component, which  will be replaced (as per per #489105).

However, current issue would still apply for both pictures and any other thumbnail capable contents such as text files.

So yes, issues are different.

However, current issue would still apply for both pictures and any other thumbnail capable contents such as text files.

So yes, issues are different.

activities.message:
Ok fair enough.
Let me talk to our Android team.

Cheers,
--Roeland
activities.markdown_message:
Ok fair enough.
Let me talk to our Android team.

Cheers,
--Roeland

activities.message:
Hi,

I have discussed this with the Android developers.
The reason they currently are exposed is when sharing resized images directly to 3rdparty apps (sending an image via signal/whatsapp for example). We are evaluating if we can limit this to only expose them during the length of the intend.

We'll keep you posted.

Cheers,
--Roeland
activities.markdown_message:
Hi,

I have discussed this with the Android developers.
The reason they currently are exposed is when sharing resized images directly to 3rdparty apps (sending an image via signal/whatsapp for example). We are evaluating if we can limit this to only expose them during the length of the intend.

We'll keep you posted.

Cheers,
--Roeland

activities.message:
Hello,
I set expose to false for DiskLruImageCacheFileProvider and only allow access if it is explicitly granted.
Currently I am facing the problem that apps using document provider should also see the thumbnails. I solved this via manually allowing "com.android.documentsui" to have access.
Maybe you have a better idea?

I created  a branch for you to check: https://github.com/nextcloud/android/tree/limitThumbnail
Can you give this a try?
activities.markdown_message:
Hello,
I set expose to false for DiskLruImageCacheFileProvider and only allow access if it is explicitly granted.
Currently I am facing the problem that apps using document provider should also see the thumbnails. I solved this via manually allowing "com.android.documentsui" to have access.
Maybe you have a better idea?

I created a branch for you to check: https://github.com/nextcloud/android/tree/limitThumbnail
Can you give this a try?

activities.message:
Hi Tobias.

I was writing but saw your reply first.

One question: can  you confirm that apps get aware of the thumbnail URI only through FileOperationsHelper? 
As DocumentsStorageProvider uses in-app URI, exported=false shall not be a problem

if yes (for FileOperationsHelper), then granting URI permission on sendCachedImage() would fix the problem without having to deal with com.android.documentsui.

Not sure what you mean by manually allowing "com.android.documentsui" to have access.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi Tobias.

I was writing but saw your reply first.

One question: can you confirm that apps get aware of the thumbnail URI only through FileOperationsHelper?
As DocumentsStorageProvider uses in-app URI, exported=false shall not be a problem

if yes (for FileOperationsHelper), then granting URI permission on sendCachedImage() would fix the problem without having to deal with com.android.documentsui.

Not sure what you mean by manually allowing "com.android.documentsui" to have access.

activities.message:
> One question: can you confirm that apps get aware of the thumbnail URI only through FileOperationsHelper? 

Yes, this is true. We allow to send cached images via FileOperationHelper, but no elsewhere.

Here we open a thumbnail from cache for DocumentStorageProvider. On line 338 you see the needed grantUriPermission.
https://github.com/nextcloud/android/blob/546eb6979b0a90ee329b5d804fd2a352d81860d3/src/main/java/com/owncloud/android/providers/DocumentsStorageProvider.java#L308-L341

Do you have an idea how to avoid this?
activities.markdown_message:
One question: can you confirm that apps get aware of the thumbnail URI only through FileOperationsHelper?

Yes, this is true. We allow to send cached images via FileOperationHelper, but no elsewhere.

Here we open a thumbnail from cache for DocumentStorageProvider. On line 338 you see the needed grantUriPermission.
https://github.com/nextcloud/android/blob/546eb6979b0a90ee329b5d804fd2a352d81860d3/src/main/java/com/owncloud/android/providers/DocumentsStorageProvider.java#L308-L341

Do you have an idea how to avoid this?

activities.message:
I see.
I am not 100% familiar with documentsui but from what I remember and often see, granting access to DocumentStorageProvider for documentsui process could be done with android.permission.MANAGE_DOCUMENTS  as readPermission constraint and then you shall keep exported=true.

Did you try this? This is  the permission that block any of my detection pattern :)
activities.markdown_message:
I see.
I am not 100% familiar with documentsui but from what I remember and often see, granting access to DocumentStorageProvider for documentsui process could be done with android.permission.MANAGE_DOCUMENTS as readPermission constraint and then you shall keep exported=true.

Did you try this? This is the permission that block any of my detection pattern :)

activities.message:
Thanks for the hint. 
I added this to AndroidManifest.xml and tested to get a thumbnail via:

`adb shell content read --uri content://org.nextcloud.imageCache.provider/image.JPG.jpg`

which results in

```
Error while accessing provider:org.nextcloud.imageCache.provider
java.lang.SecurityException: Permission Denial: reading com.owncloud.android.providers.DiskLruImageCacheFileProvider uri content://org.nextcloud.imageCache.provider/image.JPG.jpg from pid=26094, uid=2000 requires that you obtain access using ACTION_OPEN_DOCUMENT or related APIs
        at android.os.Parcel.createException(Parcel.java:1942)
        at android.os.Parcel.readException(Parcel.java:1910)
        at android.database.DatabaseUtils.readExceptionFromParcel(DatabaseUtils.java:183)
        at android.database.DatabaseUtils.readExceptionWithFileNotFoundExceptionFromParcel(DatabaseUtils.java:146)
        at android.content.ContentProviderProxy.openFile(ContentProviderNative.java:598)
        at com.android.commands.content.Content$ReadCommand.onExecute(Content.java:587)
        at com.android.commands.content.Content$Command.execute(Content.java:470)
        at com.android.commands.content.Content.main(Content.java:690)
        at com.android.internal.os.RuntimeInit.nativeFinishInit(Native Method)
        at com.android.internal.os.RuntimeInit.main(RuntimeInit.java:340)
```

But I can see the images within documents UI.

Can you verify that your attack vector is still solved?
(I did a force-push on the branch)

But I can see the images within documents UI.

Can you verify that your attack vector is still solved?
(I did a force-push on the branch)

activities.message:
Yes, fixed.

The combination of both providers now fails at the content read --uri content://org.nextcloud.imageCache.provider stage.

Julien.
activities.markdown_message:
Yes, fixed.

The combination of both providers now fails at the content read --uri content://org.nextcloud.imageCache.provider stage.

Julien.

activities.message:
Thanks a lot for your report again. This has been resolved in our latest maintenance releases and we're working on the advisories at the moment.

Please let us know how you'd like to be credited in our official advisory. We require the following information:

- Name / Pseudonym
- Email address (optional)
- Website (optional)
- Company (optional)

activities.message: Because this is only possible by installing a malicious app or using ADB, it does not qualify for a bounty.
activities.markdown_message: Because this is only possible by installing a malicious app or using ADB, it does not qualify for a bounty.

activities.message:
@nickvergessen 

Thank for the update but I am not sure what you mean here:

the issue is that any app can still data.
If you state that  because there need to be an app installed, it is not qualifying, it basically means that 99% of the issue on Android are not qualifying, is that correct? And thus "local" vector are per CVSS is simply not qualifying.

What about privacy? 
 your H1 program does not state this at all. Any possibility to reconsider this?
activities.markdown_message:
@nickvergessen

Thank for the update but I am not sure what you mean here:

the issue is that any app can still data.
If you state that because there need to be an app installed, it is not qualifying, it basically means that 99% of the issue on Android are not qualifying, is that correct? And thus "local" vector are per CVSS is simply not qualifying.

What about privacy?
your H1 program does not state this at all. Any possibility to reconsider this?

activities.message:
See https://nextcloud.com/security/threat-model/

> # Attacks involving other Android apps on the device
> 
> We do consider attacks involving other Android apps on the device as low or medium risk. Stored files can be hidden from other apps if appropriate storage option is selected inside the app. This should be secure, however, if the phone is compromised we don't guarantee data safety.
activities.markdown_message:
See https://nextcloud.com/security/threat-model/

Attacks involving other Android apps on the device

We do consider attacks involving other Android apps on the device as low or medium risk. Stored files can be hidden from other apps if appropriate storage option is selected inside the app. This should be secure, however, if the phone is compromised we don't guarantee data safety.

activities.message:
I see. 

But then, the only threat model you consider on mobile is basically privileges escalation on the API side.
Any issue on the Android app is not part of the scope, except for WEB based one.

I am not really sure what you state that the mobile apps are part of the scope then.

As this is not qualifying, any possibility to at least agree to disclose it?
activities.markdown_message:
I see.

But then, the only threat model you consider on mobile is basically privileges escalation on the API side.

As this is not qualifying, any possibility to at least agree to disclose it?

activities.message: For the credit, please see #490946
activities.markdown_message: For the credit, please see #490946

@nickvergessen

based on previous comment, can you please tell me if your decision on the bounty is final?
I really believe that having app installed on the phone capable of spying on NC storage is not synonym of "phone is compromised"

activities.message:
As discussed and similar to #518669,

I really believe that having app installed on the phone capable of spying on NC storage is not synonym of "phone is compromised"

Besides, threat model state
>  Android apps on the device
> We do consider attacks involving other Android apps on the device as low or medium risk. Stored files can be hidden from other apps if appropriate storage option is selected inside the app. This should be secure, however, if the phone is compromised we don't guarantee data safety.

here, we do are at least on attacks involving other Android apps on the device, aren't we?

activities.message: After discussing with the Android people and with my fellow Hackerone collegue who is now back from vacation, we agreed on changing this to a $100 bounty.
